newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australia Grains-Wheat futures mirror U.S.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australia Grains-Wheat futures mirror U.S.

text.p: Sydney wheat futures settled lower last week across-the-board, largely mirroring the U.S. market.

Devastating hail storms in the key wheat growing region of northern New South Wales and a bullish USDA wheat stock figure failed to rattle prices on the upside as a national bumper stock is still in sight.
Closely-watched January and March contracts settled at lows for the week of A$157.50 and A$159.50 a tonne, respectively.
However, the Sydney Futures Exchange said on Friday that the recent threat of U.S. subsidies on domestic wheat has led to U.S. wheat futures trading at subsidised price levels.
"SFE wheat futures have reflected the world export price of wheat and are currently the only true international wheat price," the exchange said.
Meanwhile, the New South Wales Grains Board said on Friday that growers who delivered malt, feed barly, sorghum and canola to its 1995/96 pools were in line for additional payments of A$30.00 a tonne
The dividend for growers follows statements earlier this week by the board that estimated pool returns for the coming harvest were at a $25.00 a tonne premium to other traders.
Graham Lawrence, the board's managing director, said the additional pool payments would reflect low world stocks coupled with an aggressive marketing campaign and a commodity hedging programme.
The additional 1995/96 pool payment of A$30 a tonne will lift canola payments to A$342.00 a tonne, he said.
A A$20.00 a tonne lift to malt barley number one will take pool payments to A$232.00 a tonne.
Also, A$20.00 increases to malt barley number two and three and feed barley number one translates into prices of A$217.00 a tonne each, while sorghum is put at up to A$187.00 a tonne.
"Once all stocks have been cleared and pool accounts finalised, a further payment can be expected by growers in early to mid-1997," Lawrence said.
On a national level, the Australian Wheat Board has said it will keep a number of options open during the harvest, with the national pool staying open throughout the harvest.

The AWB's latest pool price estimate, to be released at 0700 GMT (5:00 p.m. on Monday) is expected to be unchanged, at A$195.00 a tonne, basis Australian Standard White, the third highest pool price ever.
